Skip to contents
academicRules 1.0.0
  • Reference

Define a set of academic rules (minimum, maximum, or logical)

define_rule_set.Rd

Creates and returns an object of class "academic_ruleset", containing one or more rules. Each rule can be of type:

  • "minimum": Fail if a column is below a specified value.

  • "maximum": Fail if a column is above a specified value.

  • "logical": Fail if a row-wise logical expression evaluates to FALSE.

Usage

define_rule_set(
  rules_list = list(),
  default_outcome = "PASS",
  rule_priority = NULL
)

Arguments

rules_list

A named list of rules. Each element has:

type

Either "minimum", "maximum", or "logical".

value

(For "minimum" or "maximum") A numeric value to compare against.

dimension

(For "minimum" or "maximum") The name of a numeric column in the data.

expr

(For "logical") A formula like ~ expression, evaluated row-wise.

default_outcome

Character string giving the outcome to assign if none of the rules are triggered for a row (e.g., "PASS").

rule_priority

A character vector giving the order in which rules are applied. If NULL, the order is simply the names in rules_list.

Value

An object of class "academic_ruleset", which is essentially a list with

  • rules: the rules_list

  • default_outcome: the default outcome

  • rule_priority: the order of rule application

Examples

# A simple set of rules
my_rules <- define_rule_set(
  rules_list = list(
    "min_score" = list(type = "minimum", value = 50, dimension = "test_score"),
    "too_many_fails" = list(type = "maximum", value = 2, dimension = "fail_count"),
    "final_check" = list(type = "logical", expr = ~ subject_grade != "N")
  ),
  default_outcome = "PASS"
)
